item.title: Electron-Alert
item.description: ElectronAlert is a beautiful and developer-friendly alert for Electron applications. It is powered by SweetAlert2 and works directly from the main process. Features WithFrame and Frameless alerts that are visually stunning Toasts with timers Exception handling alert Sounds SweetAlert2-esque API* (v11) Installation npm install electron-alert Github https://github.com/rocketlaunchr/electron-alert Usage See SweetAlert2 v11 Documentation for further details (configuration & methods) Not all methods are implemented as yet.

item.title: The Final Polish - Application
item.description: The Final Polish before release Prevent a second instance of your application from running Usually, you only want one instance of your application running at any moment. const { app } = require('electron') const gotTheLock = app.requestSingleInstanceLock() if (!gotTheLock) { app.exit(0) } See: https://electronjs.org/docs/api/app#apprequestsingleinstancelock Store configuration data Users expect any customizations to their settings to persist on app reload (e.g. computer restart). You can use electron-store to save data.

item.title: The Final Polish - BrowserWindow
item.description: The Final Polish before release The BrowserWindow is actually a chromium web browser! Passing data into BrowserWindow If you use React.js for your BrowserWindow javascript, you may need to pass data from the main process to the renderer process just in time for your initial state and props. You need to know the difference between these two events: dom-ready and ready-to-show. ready-to-show event is part of BrowserWindow, and dom-ready event is part of webContents.
